And as we developed it and added features to it and changed some things around, it actually ended up becoming more of a CRM. So it has probably 90% of the same functionality as PCR9 does, but it also adds some CRM functionality. There's a deals pipeline, like a sales funnel in there. There's simpler sequencing, whole new interface, a little more configurable, So we've changed some things up a little bit into how this looks. And right now it is a second access point to your existing database. So what that means is it's going to share the same PC Recruiter database. If you wanted to add it to your database, some people could use PCRM, some people could use PCR9. It's real time, shares the same database, shares the same users. So no worries there. And the look and feel, it's kind of more of a left and right type thing. Okay. So a lot of the terminology is familiar but it looks totally different when you're looking for example at the landing page for the names search. It's going to show you by default the last 50 names you looked at. segments.text: We've added the ability to edit in line there so I could edit something live in my line as I'm looking at a list of records in the system.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: I can also go into actions here I can quick contact send an email I can call them send them a text that's using our ring central integration or I can go down here if I wanted and I can add them to a roll-up list I can add an activity I can submit a presentation or a profile show them on a map link to a position a lot of your actions that you used to have to go into the record are now available right on the results screen and you're also going to be able if I wanted to search Jim Lombardo I can type in first name last name it's going to instantly bring back all the people who match and if I choose to want to go into one of those records I'm going to be able to go right in it's gonna slide in from the left hand or the right hand side of the screen we've also changed the way the records are going to look the workspace here is going to show me kind of a custom workspace you can put maybe common fields you want to see notes if you want to show the resume the activities anything you want to put on your initial workspace details then is going to be every field you have on that person what I like about this is we've added a search up at the top if I want to get phone number fields just type in phone all the phone number fields are going to be isolated right there or if I want to look at email I can look at email it's going to look at all the email field so it gives me kind of a blanket search across every field I have on the name record in and of itself you're then going to have these tabs up at the top these are essentially what your buttons were on the PC Recruiter record if I expand my record there I'm going to be able to look at a full screen here same functionality lets you double click see the detail there and then you're going to be able to go through to the various other tabs that used to be buttons in the system some of the things like the notes screen is going to look very similar the position screen is going to look very similar the pipeline is going to look just the same so you're going to have a lot of similar bits of information, similar screens, but some things are totally different, like the resume interface, how your attachments look, how those are handled, your actions are all over here.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: So you have kind of a little bit different of a format in here.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: So I'm going to be able to kind of work within my record like that, and then I can just pop back right over into my name search there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And what we've also done is set it up so that if you go to like a company record, same stuff's all going to work same search same edit in line same actions menu same stuff so it's going to be very easy to navigate and if I go again into a company record same thing your workspace is going to be kind of your default area your landing point details is every fields you have and then your other buttons up at the top okay so have some cool things in there if you hit the little arrow it'll of explain them there shrink that back up if you need to the my pcr screen too when i go into that that is going to give me the ability to edit and maybe i want to throw like today's stats i can drag them right there maybe i want to go in here and add in also today's schedule i can put that right there so i can kind of move everything around as i wish so it kind of works in widgets You can drag and drop everything around on the screen, really wherever you want it to be.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: So I've got that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: I'm going to pull those out.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And I'm going to be able to set this up any which way I'd like.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: So a lot of the things are going to be the same.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: When you say today's schedule, does it have tasks as well?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03

segments.text: I'm just curious.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_03

segments.text: Yeah.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Well, if you had it, that's going to be your schedule.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: I don't think there's a task list on it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: It just shows your schedule.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: Makes sense.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_04

segments.text: Yeah.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_04

segments.text: It's just going to show your schedule and what's on it that day.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: And the schedule is going to look very much the same.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: It still has your task list if you use it right up there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

segments.text: So you'd still have that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_02

transcription.srt_content:
1
00:00:00,100 --> 00:00:00,850
Welcome to Zoom.

2
00:00:00,950 --> 00:00:02,700
Enter your meeting ID followed by pound.

3
00:00:02,800 --> 00:00:03,800
Enter your participant ID.

4
00:00:26,224 --> 00:00:28,920
Please enter the meeting password followed by pound.

5
00:00:30,221 --> 00:00:31,004
You are in the meeting now.

6
00:00:35,980 --> 00:00:38,310
There are three participants in the meeting.

7
00:00:41,148 --> 00:00:41,536
Good afternoon.

8
00:00:41,760 --> 00:00:42,031
This is Jim.

9
00:00:46,560 --> 00:00:47,142
Hello, Chris.

10
00:00:52,800 --> 00:00:53,200
Do you hear me?

11
00:00:55,007 --> 00:00:55,697
Hey, I can hear you.

12
00:00:56,702 --> 00:00:59,196
Haley, I know you're super busy.

13
00:01:00,060 --> 00:01:00,481
If you want to,

14
00:01:00,501 --> 00:01:03,208
maybe me and Jim can record this and then you can,

15
00:01:03,228 --> 00:01:03,408
you know,

16
00:01:03,448 --> 00:01:06,536
you can join in because I know you're super busy.

17
00:01:08,300 --> 00:01:08,848
Jim, it's up to you.

18
00:01:10,521 --> 00:01:12,839
Yeah, we can record this so that you can have it and share it.

19
00:01:13,882 --> 00:01:14,046
Yeah.

20
00:01:14,541 --> 00:01:14,747
Yeah.

21
00:01:15,200 --> 00:01:15,588
Okay, Haley.

22
00:01:16,220 --> 00:01:17,318
And that way you can go on.

23
00:01:17,766 --> 00:01:18,560
I know you're super busy.

24
00:01:18,722 --> 00:01:19,107
So, all right.

25
00:01:20,545 --> 00:01:20,808
Cool.

26
00:01:21,862 --> 00:01:23,016
Although you're welcome to stay as well.

27
00:01:23,605 --> 00:01:24,399
Just totally up to you.

28
00:01:26,964 --> 00:01:29,739
I'll record it regardless and I'll send it over to you after we're done.

29
00:01:30,344 --> 00:01:30,700
Thanks, man.

30
00:01:32,680 --> 00:01:33,816
I forget where you're recording.

31
00:01:34,140 --> 00:01:34,578
Oh, you know what?

32
00:01:34,700 --> 00:01:34,832
Let me.

33
00:01:39,341 --> 00:01:40,626
This meeting is being recorded.

34
00:01:44,583 --> 00:01:44,907
All right.

35
00:01:47,902 --> 00:01:48,166
All right.

36
00:01:49,200 --> 00:01:51,336
So what we're going to take a look at today is the PCRM piece.

37
00:01:52,140 --> 00:01:52,450
Is that right?

38
00:01:53,180 --> 00:01:54,220
That's what we're going to take a look at there.

39
00:01:56,320 --> 00:01:56,496
Yes.

40
00:01:57,448 --> 00:01:57,677
Okay.

41
00:01:58,060 --> 00:02:00,879
PCRM and the AI talk a little bit about that too.

42
00:02:01,340 --> 00:02:04,647
So a little bit of background of where this came from and what has happened here.

43
00:02:11,000 --> 00:02:13,305
We had some years ago decided we were going to redesign PCRecruiter,

44
00:02:13,325 --> 00:02:16,432
and PCR9 was going to be redesigned into what we were at the time calling PCR10.

45
00:02:20,763 --> 00:02:20,991
Hello.

46
00:02:21,643 --> 00:02:21,885
Now, PCR10 – Yep.

47
00:02:23,780 --> 00:02:24,100
Do you hear me?

48
00:02:24,181 --> 00:02:24,309
Hello.

49
00:02:26,361 --> 00:02:27,234
Do you hear me, Chris?

50
00:02:27,952 --> 00:02:28,060
Hello.

51
00:02:28,582 --> 00:02:29,532
Yes, I can hear you fine.

52
00:02:30,945 --> 00:02:31,551
Haley, can you hear?

53
00:02:35,543 --> 00:02:35,746
Hello.

54
00:02:37,505 --> 00:02:38,359
I can hear her just fine.

55
00:02:38,783 --> 00:02:39,873
I don't think she can hear us.

56
00:02:40,740 --> 00:02:41,755
Now, can you all hear me?

57
00:02:42,240 --> 00:02:43,160
I can hear you all now.

58
00:02:43,783 --> 00:02:43,957
Yes.

59
00:02:45,282 --> 00:02:45,423
Sorry.

60
00:02:48,140 --> 00:02:48,408
No worries.

61
00:02:49,043 --> 00:02:49,460
I can hear you.

62
00:02:50,866 --> 00:02:51,279
All right.

63
00:02:52,361 --> 00:02:55,795
So what we did, we designed, this was going to be a replacement for PCR9.

64
00:02:56,940 --> 00:02:59,260
It was going to be a whole new interface for the package.

65
00:02:59,501 --> 00:03:02,428
And as we developed it and added features to it and changed some things around,

66
00:03:02,489 --> 00:03:04,013
it actually ended up becoming more of a CRM.

67
00:03:06,840 --> 00:03:09,866
So it has probably 90% of the same functionality as PCR9 does,

68
00:03:09,886 --> 00:03:11,189
but it also adds some CRM functionality.

69
00:03:16,940 --> 00:03:19,560
There's a deals pipeline, like a sales funnel in there.

70
00:03:20,041 --> 00:03:21,884
There's simpler sequencing,

71
00:03:21,904 --> 00:03:22,706
whole new interface,

72
00:03:22,726 --> 00:03:23,748
a little more configurable,

73
00:03:23,768 --> 00:03:26,113
So we've changed some things up a little bit into how this looks.

74
00:03:29,900 --> 00:03:33,216
And right now it is a second access point to your existing database.

75
00:03:34,180 --> 00:03:36,516
So what that means is it's going to share the same PC Recruiter database.

76
00:03:37,802 --> 00:03:39,147
If you wanted to add it to your database,

77
00:03:39,167 --> 00:03:40,873
some people could use PCRM,

78
00:03
transcription.summary:
This conversation appears to be a recording of a phone call between two individuals, likely Jim and the speaker. The topic of discussion is PCRM (PC Recruiter Modern), a software product that has been updated from its predecessor, PCR9.

The speaker asks Jim about the differences between PCRM and PCR9, and Jim explains that PCRM is essentially an enhancement to PCR9 with a more modern look and feel. However, it's mentioned that there are still users on PCR8 and earlier versions, which have been shut down.

Jim also mentions that there are two products being supported now: PCRM and PCR9, but the ultimate goal is to transition everyone to PCRM eventually. The adoption rate of PCRM is low, with most customers still using PCR9 or just starting to use PCRM.

The speaker expresses interest in providing feedback on PCRM and asks if they can be sent a link to explore it further. They also mention that Crelate is a step more expensive than PCRM but acknowledges that it's a different product.

Overall, the conversation seems to be an informal discussion between two individuals exploring the updates and changes made to PCRM compared to its predecessor, PCR9.
